entry.title: Women presenters and lack thereof
entry.content:
After months of planning with my amazing colleagues - Annie Conn, Bonna Choi, and Nancy Chu - we successfully organized the first ever ThoughtWorks sponsored Girl Geek Dinner.

Once the venue, catering, and audio/equipment rentals were confirmed ... the next thing on my list was to find WOMEN speakers. Much to my surprise this was the hardest part of the organizing bit! When I thought about who I'd want to invite to be one of my speakers, I quickly thought of our Chief Technology Officer - Rebecca Parsons. After jotting down Rebecca, I remember having to really think hard about my next set of speaker prospects. Though I eventually came up with 4-5 potential ThoughtWorks women speakers, all of them were out of state! Ideally, I could have flown them in but that's not very cost effective especially when each talk would range anywhere from 5-10 mins.

In the end, I decided to look within the ThoughtWorks San Francisco community. By doing so, I was faced with a lot of the same excuses ... "I can't, I have other plans that day.", "I would, but I don't know what I'd talk about." and perhaps the most common one of all (which coincidentally was my excuse initially) ...

I've never done a talk in front of a large audience before and I'm utterly terrified of speaking in public.

Where are the women presenters?

Thought about flying people in. Some had things they wanted to talk about but were too afraid to do the talk. Nervous, no experience.

Tips:

  • Jump at the opportunity
  • Practice!
  • Engage the audience.
  • Speak slowly and annunciate
  • Don't read
  • Look up
  • Focus on one person. talk as if you're talking to them.
  • Make it fun!
  • Use simple slides
  • include photos
